title: The encouragement of tears as a concomitant of contrition had a long history. The fourth-century bishop, Ambrose of Milan, stated that Christ the physician, when treating us in confession, ‘orders therapeutic baths through our outpouring of tears’. Such passages were routinely included in medieval manuals of penance as, for instance, in Walter Cantilupe’s Summula for the diocese of Exeter, issued in 1240
